tn.text: Though this letter is from Paul and Timothy to the Colossian believers, later in the letter Paul makes it clear that he is the writer. Most likely Timothy was with him and wrote the words down as Paul spoke.

Throughout this letter the words "we," "our," and "ours" include the Colossians unless noted otherwise. The words "you," "your," and "yours" refer to the Colossian believers and so are plural unless noted otherwise. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: an apostle of Christ Jesus through the will of God
tn.text: "whom God chose to be an apostle of Christ Jesus"

tn.ref: We give ... our Lord ... we always
tn.text: These words do not include the Colossians. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
Paul is excluding his audience. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
"your belief in Christ Jesus"

tn.ref: because of the confident expectation reserved for you in heaven
tn.text: Here "confident expectation" stands for what the believer can confidently expect, that is, the things that God has promised to do for all believers. These things are spoken of as if they were physical objects that God was keeping in heaven for the believers to possess later. AT: "because you are certain that God, who is in heaven, will do the many good things that he has promised you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Paul is speaking here of the gospel as if it were a tree or plant that grows and produces food. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The gospel is spreading and growing throughout the known world. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: the grace of God in truth
tn.text: "the true grace of God"

tn.ref: our beloved ... our behalf ... to us
tn.text: The words "our" and "us" do not include the Colossians. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])

tn.ref: gospel as you learned it from Epaphras, our beloved fellow servant, who
tn.text: "gospel. It is exactly what you learned from Epaphras, who is our beloved fellow servant and who" or "gospel. It is exactly what Epaphras, our beloved fellow servant, taught you. He"

tn.ref: Epaphras, our beloved fellow servant, who is a faithful servant of Christ on our behalf
tn.text: Here "on our behalf" means that Epaphras was doing work for Christ that Paul himself would have done if he were not in prison.
the man who preached the gospel to the people in Colossae (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Paul speaks of the Holy Spirit as if he were a place in which the believers were located. AT: "how the Holy Spirit has enabled you to love believers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Because the Spirit has enabled them to love others, Paul prays for them and tells them here how he prays for them.
"Because the Holy Spirit has enabled you to love other believers"

tn.ref: we heard ... we have not stopped ... We have been asking ... We have been praying
tn.text: These words do not include the Colossians. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])

tn.ref: from the day we heard this
tn.text: "from the day Epaphras told us these things"

tn.ref: that you will be filled with the knowledge of his will
tn.text: Paul speaks of the Colossian believers as though they were containers. AT: "that God will fill you with what you need to know so that you can do his will" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: in all wisdom and spiritual understanding
tn.text: ", so that the Holy Spirit will make you wise and able to understand what God wants you to do"

tn.ref: that you will walk worthily of the Lord
tn.text: Walking here signifies behavior in life. AT: "that you will live the way God expects you to" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"in ways that will please the Lord"

Paul is speaking of the Colossian believers as if they were trees or plants. As a plant grows and bears fruit, so also believers are to keep getting to know God better and doing good deeds. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word "we" refers to Paul and Timothy but not to the Colossians. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])

Paul speaks of the Colossian believers as if God would move them into a location of perseverance and patience. In reality, he is praying that they will never stop trusting in God and that they will be completely patient as they honor him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: has made you able to have a share
tn.text: "has allowed you to share"
Here Paul is focusing on his readers as receivers of God's blessings. But he does not mean that he himself has no share in those blessings.
Receiving what God has promised believers is spoken of as if it were inheriting property and wealth from a family member. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This idea is opposite to the idea of the dominion of darkness in the next verse. AT: "in the glory of his presence"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Paul talks about the ways in which Christ is excellent.
"God the Father has rescued"
Darkness is a common picture in the scriptures for evil. AT: "the power of evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"God the Father's beloved Son, Jesus Christ"

tn.ref: In his Son we have redemption
tn.text: Paul often speaks as if the believers were "in" Jesus Christ or "in" God. Here this expression can also be translated as "by means of his Son we have redemption."  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"; his Son forgives our sins" or "; the Father forgives us through his Son"

tn.ref: The Son is the image of the invisible God
tn.text: Here "image" does not mean a representation of something that is visible. Instead, "image" here means that by knowing the Son, we learn what God the Father is like.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is an important title for Jesus, the Son of God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])

"The Son is the firstborn." The expression "firstborn Son" does not refer to Jesus' birth in Bethlehem. Instead, it refers to the Son's position as the eternal Son of God the Father. In this sense, "firstborn" is a metaphor meaning "most important." Jesus is the most important and the unique "Son" of God. He is God. The word "Son" shows Jesus' intimate relationship with the Father. That relationship cannot be understood until and unless you use your language's words for "son" and "father."  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: For by him all things were created
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Because the Son created all things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Whether thrones or dominions or governments or authorities, all things were created by him and for him
tn.text: The Son created all things for himself, including thrones, dominions, principalities, and authorities. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"He existed before all things"

tn.ref: in him all things hold together
tn.text: Paul is speaking here of the Son controlling all things as if he were physically holding them together. "he holds everything together" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"Jesus Christ, the Son of God, is the head"

tn.ref: he is the head of the body, the church
tn.text: Paul speaks of Jesus' position over the church as if he were the head on the human body. As the head rules the body, so does Jesus rule the church. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"the originating authority." He is the first chief or founder.
Jesus is the first person to die and come back to life, never to die again.
This is an important title for Jesus, the Son of God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])

tn.ref: through the blood of his cross
tn.text: "by means of the blood Jesus shed on the cross"
Here "blood" stands for the death of Christ on the cross. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Paul makes it clear that God has now revealed that Christ exchanges the sin of Gentile believers for his holiness.
"And you Colossian believers also"
"were like people whom God did not know" or "had pushed God away"

tn.ref: to present you holy, blameless, and above reproach before him
tn.text: Paul is describing the Colossians as though Jesus had physically cleaned them, put them in clean clothes, and brought them to stand before God the Father. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Paul uses two words that mean almost the same thing to emphasize the idea of perfection. AT: "perfect" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This expression of location stands for "in God's view" or "in God's mind" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
that believers proclaimed (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: to every person created under heaven
tn.text: "to every person in the world"

tn.ref: the gospel of which I, Paul, became a servant
tn.text: Paul was actually a servant of God. AT: "the gospel that I, Paul, serve God by proclaiming" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I fill up in my flesh what is lacking of the afflictions of Christ
tn.text: Paul speaks about the suffering that he continues to experience. He may be acknowledging here that there is much suffering that he and all other Christians must endure before Christ comes again, and that Christ in a spiritual sense joins with them in experiencing these hardships. Paul certainly does not mean that Christ's sufferings alone were not enough to provide salvation for the believers.

tn.ref: I fill up in my flesh
tn.text: Paul speaks of his body as if it were a container that could hold suffering. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: for the sake of his body, which is the church
tn.text: Paul often speaks of the church, the group of all Christian believers, as if it were Christ's body. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: to fulfill the word of God
tn.text: This means to bring about the purpose of God's gospel message, which is that it be preached and believed. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: This is the secret truth that was hidden
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "This is the secret truth that God had hidden" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The words "ages" and "generations" refer to the time period from the creation of the world until the time when the gospel was preached.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "now God has revealed it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the riches of the glory of this secret truth
tn.text: Paul speaks of the value of this secret truth about God as if it were a treasure of material wealth. "riches" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Paul speaks of the believers as if they were actual containers in which Christ is present. This is one of his ways of expressing the union of the believers with Christ. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"so you can confidently expect to share in God's glory" (see UDB)

tn.ref: we proclaim ... We admonish ... we teach ... we may present
tn.text: These words do not include the Colossians. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
"We warn everyone"

tn.ref: so that we may present every person
tn.text: "so that we may present to God every person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"spiritually mature" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
